blog.name: literarygalpals
blog.title: WGS 2256: Gal Pals
blog.description: We are an undergraduate class at Vanderbilt University working our way through a course on relationships between women across literary and cultural history. Here, each member of our course will post responses to our readings or viewings of the week.

title: Killing Eve, 1x01/02
body:
As others have noted, a theme that emerged early on in “Killing Eve” is the idea that women who kill are inherently non-nurturing and unnatural - how many ‘normal’ women would go out of their way to ruin a child’s day? While Villanelle (BTW, can we talk about how her name is literally “villan” + “elle” - like “villain” + “elle” - “she-villain”…) is clearly disturbed, Eve’s non-conformity is more subtle. “Eve” is the Biblical mother of all humanity and the cause of its descent into sin because she gave into temptation. But, the Eve in the show is portrayed as relatively non-maternal. She technically endangers a minor (Dom), laughs about Frank’s children growing up motherless and with a drunk father, and immediately after that scene, her husband points out that she’s “glowing”. Women are usually described as glowing when they’re pregnant; instead, Eve is glowing because she has a new job hunting down a prolific assassin. If Villanelle is the serpent tempting Eve going forward, I’m interested to see how that temptation plays out. There’s clearly a sexual element, as Villanelle appears to be bisexual and Eve is a little too interested in female assassins - when her husband asks if she’s agreed to work for MI6 just to help stop a killer, she can’t answer.

-Amber

body:
Killing Eve

How sick and gay am I that I ship Eve and Villanelle so fucking bad.

Okay what I have yet to see that ↑ episode but this episode↓ that shit was enough for.

Uggghhhhhh need me a psycho assassin who’s obsessed with me.

Update SPOILER

  • Eve is a back stabbing bitch
  • Eve is a traitor
  • Villanelle is a doll who wants love
  • Villanelle deserves “someone to watch movies with”
  • Eve is a closeted lesbian
  • Why does she even wanna kill Villanelle???

summary: Oooookay, but has anyone listened to this song for Killing Eve that I don’t think I heard anywhere in the series but is...
body:
Oooookay, but has anyone listened to this song for Killing Eve that I don’t think I heard anywhere in the series but is incredibly gay????

Like,

“I rose to kiss her but the flower fell apart?”

“‘Where does love go,’ she said. I said, ‘wherever you are’”

Please give it a listen. Very interesting how it portrays Eve and Villanelle’s relationship.


Edit: it was played in the scene where Konstantin is at his home (thank you @agentlewomancarter !!) I’m still curious as to interpreting this song and it’s lyrics! Let’s discuss!

blog.name: literarygalpals
blog.title: WGS 2256: Gal Pals
blog.description: We are an undergraduate class at Vanderbilt University working our way through a course on relationships between women across literary and cultural history. Here, each member of our course will post responses to our readings or viewings of the week.

title:
"Killing Eve, 1x01"
 Pheobe Waller-Bridge
body:
Just before watching the scene where Villanelle kills the man in Tuscany, I tried to prepare myself to watch, really cover my eyes during,  a potentially violent and gory assassination. However, I almost forgot to squint through the killing because I was caught off guard by a comment the assassin makes. Only a moment before killing the man with the “nice face,” Villanelle responds to him stroking her face: “You should really ask before touching a person.” With this, I shared a moment of agreement with Villanelle; then, I quickly remembered that she is the villain. I think this dismissal was so easy, not only because Villanelle is a killer, but because she is opposite another female lead, Eve. I realize that the characterization of Villanelle is playing into the psycho lesbian or even crazy feminist trope, but it feels tempting to overlook this. By making Eve a strong female lead, who appears to be on the side of justice, the creators of Killing Eve counterbalance Villanelle’s character. You don’t have to be mad at women being portrayed as psychotic, sexualized tools because through Eve women are also depicted as driven and intelligent. This is obviously ignoring a lot of other issues, but having only watched the first episode the potential strategy of counterbalancing two strong, opposing female leads stands out. It will be interesting to see if this method withstands the entire season.

-Leoncia

blog.name: keiraquotes
blog.title: Keira Knightley Quotes
blog.description: Quotes from the often foul-mouthed English actress, Keira Knightley. And sometimes quotes from her co-stars, directors, and admirers.

summary: “Sandra Oh is absolutely amazing, but that psycho killer [Jodie Comer’s Villanelle] is the only part that I’ve ever been really,...
body:
“Sandra Oh is absolutely amazing, but that psycho killer [Jodie Comer’s Villanelle] is the only part that I’ve ever been really, really jealous that I didn’t play…. It is such a f—ing amazing psycho, I would really have liked to put my teeth into that. Jodie was f—ing amazing…. I totally loved watching that moment when she turns around in the club and she kills [spoiler] and she’s like a shark coming through that club. I just loved that so much. That image is totally stuck in my head now.”

Keira Knightley on binge watching “Killing Eve”

reblog.comment:

I totally loved watching that moment when she turns around in the club and she kills [spoiler] and she’s like a shark coming through that club. I just loved that so much. That image is totally stuck in my head now.”

blog.description:
“The anthropologists got it wrong when they named our species Homo sapiens ('wise man'). In any case it's an arrogant and bigheaded thing to say, wisdom being one of our least evident features. In reality, we are Pan narrans, the storytelling chimpanzee.” 
― Terry Pratchett, The Science of Discworld II: The Globe

summary: Killing Eve – Codename Villanelle di Luke Jennings
title: Killing Eve – Codename Villanelle di Luke Jennings
body:
Killing Eve – Codename Villanelle di Luke Jennings

Dal 27 novembre in libreria

Tra pochi giorni in libreria Killing Eve – Codename Villanelle, di  Luke Jennings. Killing Eve – Codename Villanelleè un romanzo rivoluzionario che sfida gli stereotipi dei thriller affidando a due donne ruoli solitamente maschili, due donne tenaci, ostinate, a prova di bomba, ma al tempo stesso piene di contraddizioni e fragilità. Una storia cruenta e carica di…

View On WordPress
